item.title: Pascal's Identity
item.description:
Pascal’s Identity, also known as Pascal’s Rule, expresses a binomial coefficient in \(n\) as the sum of two binomial coefficients in \(n-1\). \(\definecolor{brightyellow}{RGB}{222,255,0}\) \(\definecolor{brightred}{RGB}{255,0,188}\) \(\definecolor{brightgreen}{RGB}{3,255,0}\) \(\definecolor{brightblue}{RGB}{0,205,255}\) \(\definecolor{brightpurple} {RGB}{133,0,255}\) \(\renewcommand{\redbox}[1]{\fcolorbox{black}{brightred}{#1}}\) \(\renewcommand{\greenbox}[1]{\fcolorbox{black}{brightgreen}{#1}}\) \(\renewcommand{\bluebox}[1]{\fcolorbox{black}{brightblue}{#1}}\) \(\renewcommand{\yellowbox}[1]{\fcolorbox{black}{brightyellow}{#1}}\) \(\renewcommand{\purplebox}[1]{\fcolorbox{black}{brightpurple}{#1}}\) \(\renewcommand{\qedsymbol}{\rule{0.5em}{0.5em}}\)

Theorem 1 (Pascal’s Identity) For integers \(n\) and \(k\), where \(k \le n\), Pascal’s Identity is given by the identity

\[\begin{equation} { n \choose k} = {n-1 \choose k-1} + {n-1 \choose k} \end{equation}\]

Proof

\[\begin{aligned} {n \choose k} = & \ \ { n \choose k} \\[1em] = & \ \ \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!} \\[1em] = & \ \ \frac{(n-1)!}{(k-1)!(n-1-k)!} \left[ \frac{n}{(n-k)k} \right] \\[1em] = & \ \ \frac{(n-1)!}{(k-1)!(n-1-k)!} \left[ \frac{1}{(n-k)}+ \frac{1}{k}\right] \\[1em] = & \ \ \left[ \frac{(n-1)!}{(k-1)!(n-k)!} + \frac{(n-1)!}{k!(n-1-k)!} \right] \\[1em] = & \ \ {n-1 \choose k-1} + {n-1 \choose k} \\[1em] & & \qedsymbol \end{aligned}\]

When using Pascal’s Triangle, the relationship between these combinations are apparent. For example, suppose \(n=5\) and \(k=2\), then Pascal’s Identity states

\[\begin{aligned} \bluebox{ ${ 5 \choose 2}$ } = \ \ & \greenbox{ ${5-1 \choose 2-1}$ } + \greenbox{ ${5-1 \choose 2}$ } \\[1em] = \ \ & \greenbox{ ${4 \choose 1}$ } + \greenbox{ ${4 \choose 2}$ }. \\[1em] \end{aligned}\]

The pattern is clear in Pascal’s Triangle.

\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${0 \choose 0}$} }\ \ \ \end{equation}\]\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${1 \choose 0}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${1 \choose 1}$} }\ \ \ \end{equation}\]\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${2 \choose 0}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${2 \choose 1}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${2 \choose 2}$} }\ \ \ \end{equation}\]\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${3 \choose 0}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${3 \choose 1}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${3 \choose 2}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${3 \choose 3}$} }\ \ \ \end{equation}\]\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${4 \choose 0}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{black}{brightgreen}{${4 \choose 1}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{black}{brightgreen}{${4 \choose 2}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${4 \choose 3}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${4 \choose 4}$} }\ \ \ \end{equation}\]\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${5 \choose 0}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${5 \choose 1}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{black}{brightblue}{${5 \choose 2}$} }\ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${5 \choose 3}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${5 \choose 4}$} }\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ { \fcolorbox{transparent}{transparent}{${5 \choose 5}$} }\ \ \ \ \end{equation}\]

item.title: Pascal's Triangle
item.description:
Pascal’s Triangle organizes the binomial coefficients in a triangular stack with one row of coefficients stacked upon another. While simple in both form and construction, Pascal’s Triangle contains a wealth of patterns in combinatorics.

\[\begin{aligned} (a+b)^3 & = \ \bluebox{1}a^3 + \bluebox{3}a^2b + \bluebox{3}ab^2 + \bluebox{1}b^3 \\[1em] & = \ a^3 + 3a^2b + 3ab^2 + b^3. \end{aligned}\]

The \(n^{th}\) row in Pascal’s Triangle is a sequence of combinations \({n \choose k}\) for \(0 \le k \lt n\), for example

\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ {\scriptsize { 0 \choose 0 } = 1}\ \ \ \end{equation}\]\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ {\scriptsize { 1 \choose 0 } = 1}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 1 \choose 1 } = 1}\ \ \ \end{equation}\]\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ {\scriptsize { 2 \choose 0 } = 1}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 2 \choose 1 } = 2}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 2 \choose 2 } = 1}\ \ \ \end{equation}\]\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ {\scriptsize { 3 \choose 0 } = 1}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 3 \choose 1 } = 3}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 3 \choose 2 } = 3}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 3 \choose 3 } = 1}\ \ \ \end{equation}\]\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ {\scriptsize { 4 \choose 0 } = 1}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 4 \choose 1 } = 4}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 4 \choose 2 } = 6}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 4 \choose 3 } = 4}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 4 \choose 4 } = 1}\ \ \ \end{equation}\]\[\begin{equation}\ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 5 \choose 0 } = 1}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 5 \choose 1 } = 5}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 5 \choose 2 } = 10}\ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 5 \choose 3 } = 10}\ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 5 \choose 4 } = 5}\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ {\scriptsize { 5 \choose 5 } = 1}\ \ \ \ \end{equation}\]

Click to view: How Blaise Pascal viewed Pascal's Triangle

While Pascal’s Triangle receives its name from the French mathematician Blaise Pascal (1623-1662), Pascal’s Triangle has been extensively studied well before the efforts of Blaise Pascal. According to Pengelley (Pengelley, n.d.), Blaise Pascal studied his Pascal’s Triangle in a form different from how we consider his triangle today. Namely, Pascal studied his triangle in rows and columns as shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1: Pascal’s Triangle from Pascal’s
‘Treatise on the Arithmetical Triangle’.

Pascal considered his form as a generator of a triangle beginning with an arbitrary value placed in the top left-most position. For demonstration, Pascal set this arbitrary value to be one. According to Pascal (Pengelley, n.d.),

The number of the first cell, which is at the right angle, is arbitrary; but that number having been assigned, all the rest are determined, and for this reason it is called the generator of the triangle. Each of the others is specified by a single rule as follows:

The number of each cell is equal to the sum of the numbers of the perpendicular and parallel cells immediately preceding. Thus cell F, that is, the number of cell F, equals the sum of cell C and cell E, and similarly with the rest.

As noted in Pascal’s form of his triangle, a particular value, say \(\bluebox{10}\), is determined as the sum of the two values, one immediately above and another immediately to its left, \((\greenbox{6} + \greenbox{4})\) in this example.

item.title: The Binomial Theorem - Proof
item.description:
The binomial theorem is a true work-horse in the area of combinatorics, probability, and statistics. In particular, the binomial theorem is the theoretical basis for experiments whose random variable exhibits a binomial distribution.

For example, a random experiment that exhibits a binomial distribution is an experiment that counts the number of \(k\) successes in \(n\) independent Bernoulli trials with a probability equal to \(\rho \ge 0\).

More broadly speaking, the binomial theorem is an excellent tool for analyzing many combinatoric expressions, such as

\[\begin{equation} \sum^n_{k=0} {n \choose k} = 2^n \end{equation}\]

and

\[\begin{equation} \sum^n_{k=0} (-1)^k {n \choose k} = 0. \end{equation}\]

Historically speaking, knowledge of the binomial theorem is quite old. According to Goss (Goss 2011), scholars trace the binomial theorem to “the \(4^{th}\) century B.C. and Euclid where one finds the formula for \((a + b )^2\).” And, “in the \(3^{rd}\) century B.C. the Indian mathematician Pingala presented what is now known as ‘Pascal’s triangle’ [which arranges] binomial coefficients in a triangle.”

Theorems

Theorem 1 (The Binomial Coefficient) For non-negative \(n\) and \(0 \le k \le n\),

\[\begin{equation} {n \choose k} = \frac {n!}{k!(n-k)!} \end{equation}\]

is called a binomial coefficient.

Theorem 2 (The Binomial Theorem) The binomial theorem states for real or complex \(a, b,\) and non-negative \(n\),

\[\begin{equation} (a+b)^n = \sum^n_{k=0} {n \choose k} a^{n-k}b^k \end{equation}\]

where \({n \choose k} = \frac {n!}{k!(n-k)!}\) is a binomial coefficient (AoPS 2021).

Binomial Coefficients

The binomial coefficients are the coefficients that result from expanding an \(n^{th}\)-order binomial. For example, expanding the binomial expression \((a+b)^4\) yields the expression

\[\begin{equation} (a+b)^4 = a^4 + 4a^3b + 6a^2b^2 + 4ab^3 + b^4, \end{equation}\]

where the coefficients, \(1\), \(4\), and \(6\), are the binomial coefficients expressed by the binomial theorem. Namely,

\[\begin{align} (a+b)^4 = & \ \sum^4_{k=0} {4 \choose k} a^{4-k}b^k \\[1em] = & \ {4 \choose 0} a^4 + {4 \choose 1} a^3b + {4 \choose 2} a^2b^2 + {4 \choose 3} ab^3 + {4 \choose 4} b^4 \\[1em] = & \ a^4 + 4a^3b + 6a^2b^2 + 4ab^3 + b^4, \\[1em] \end{align}\]

where \({4 \choose k}= \frac{4!}{k!(4-k)!}\) for \(k \in \{0, 1, 2, 3, 4\}\).

Proof of the Binomial Theorem

We prove the binomial theorem by induction. For our basis step, we show that the binomial theorem holds for \(n=1\),

\[\begin{align} (a+b)^1 & = \sum^1_{k=0} {1 \choose k} a^{1-k}b^k \\[1em] & = {1 \choose 0} a + {1 \choose 1} b \\[1em] & = 1 a + 1 b \\[1em] & = a + b. \\ \end{align}\]

For our inductive step, we assume the binomial theorem for \(n\),

\[\begin{equation} (a+b)^n = \sum^n_{k=0} {n \choose k} a^{n-k}b^k, \tag{1} \end{equation}\]

and then show that the binomial theorem for \(n+1\) follows,

\[\begin{equation} (a+b)^{n+1} = \sum^{n+1}_{k=0} {{n+1} \choose k} a^{{n+1}-k}b^k. \end{equation}\]

To begin, we multiply both sides of Eq. (1) by the term \((a+b)\),

\[\begin{align} (a+b)^n \cdot (a+b) = & \left[ \sum^n_{k=0} {n \choose k} a^{n-k}b^k \right] \cdot (a+b) \\[1em] (a+b)^{n+1} = & \left[ \sum^n_{k=0} {n \choose k} a^{n-k}b^k \right] \cdot (a+b). \tag{2} \end{align}\]

Next, we expand the summation in Eq. (2)

\[\begin{equation} { \scriptstyle \begin{gathered} (a\ + \ b)^{n\ + \ 1} \ = \\[1em] \left[ {n \choose 0} a^n \ + \ {n \choose 1} a^{n-1}b \ + \ \\[1em] {n \choose 2} a^{n-2}b^2 \ + \ \ \cdot\cdot\cdot \ \ + \ {n \choose n-1} ab^{n-1} \ + \ {n \choose n} b^n. \right] \cdot (a\ + \ b). \end{gathered} } \end{equation}\]

Now, we distribute the binomial \((a+b)\) over this expanded summation,

\[\begin{equation} { \scriptstyle \begin{gathered} (a\ + \ b)^{n\ + \ 1} \ = \\[1em] \left[ {n \choose 0} a^n\cdot a \ + \ {n \choose 1} a^{n-1}b\cdot a \ + \ {n \choose 2} a^{n-2}b^2\cdot a \ + \ \ \cdot\cdot\cdot \ \ + \ {n \choose n-1} ab^{n-1}\cdot a \ + \ {n \choose n} b^n\cdot a \right] \ \ + \ \\[1em] \left[ {n \choose 0} a^n\cdot b \ + \ {n \choose 1} a^{n-1}b\cdot b \ + \ {n \choose 2} a^{n-2}b^2\cdot b \ + \ \ \cdot\cdot\cdot \ \ + \ {n \choose n-1} ab^{n-1}\cdot b \ + \ {n \choose n} b^n\cdot b \right]. \\[2em] \end{gathered} } \end{equation}\]

From here, we update the exponents for \(a\) and \(b\),

\[\begin{equation} { \scriptstyle \begin{gathered} (a\ + \ b)^{n\ + \ 1} \ = \\[1em] \left[ {n \choose 0} a^{n\ + \ 1} \ + \ {n \choose 1} a^{n}b \ + \ {n \choose 2} a^{n-1}b^2 \ + \ \cdot\cdot\cdot \ + \ {n \choose n-1} a^{2}b^{n-1} \ + \ {n \choose n} ab^n \right] \ \ + \ \\[1em] \left[ {n \choose 0} a^nb \ + \ {n \choose 1} a^{n-1}b^2 \ + \ {n \choose 2} a^{n-2}b^3 \ + \ \cdot\cdot\cdot \ + \ {n \choose n-1} ab^{n} \ + \ {n \choose n} b^{n\ + \ 1} \right]. \end{gathered} } \end{equation}\]

Now, we collect like terms,

\[\begin{equation} { \scriptstyle \begin{aligned} (a\ + \ b)^{n\ + \ 1} = & \ \ {n \choose 0} a^{n\ + \ 1} \\[1em] & \left[ {n \choose 0} \ + \ {n \choose 1} \right] a^nb \ \ + \ \\[1em] & \left[ {n \choose 1} \ + \ {n \choose 2} \right] a^{n-1}b^2 \ \ + \ \\[1em] & ... \\[1em] & \left[ {n \choose n-1} \ + \ {n \choose n-2} \right] a^2b^{n-1} \ \ + \ \\[1em] & \left[ {n \choose n} \ + \ {n \choose n-1} \right] ab^n \ \ + \ \\[1em] & {n \choose n} b^{n\ + \ 1}. \end{aligned} } \tag{3} \end{equation}\]

Next, we apply two transformations to Eq. (3). First, we change the outermost binomial coefficients from \({n \choose 0}\) and \({n \choose n}\) to \({n+1 \choose 0}\) and\({n+1 \choose n+1}\), respectively; and then second, we apply Pascal’s Rule

\[\begin{gathered} \mathbf{\text{Pascal's Rule}} \\[1em] {n \choose k} = {n-1 \choose k-1} + {n-1 \choose k} \end{gathered}\]

to the innermost binomial coefficients. These two transformation yield the expression

\[\begin{equation} { \scriptstyle \begin{gathered} (a\ + \ b)^{n\ + \ 1} \ = \\[1em] {n \ +\ 1 \choose 0} a^{n\ + \ 1} \ \ + \ {n \ + \ 1 \choose 1} a^nb \ \ + \ {n \ + \ 1 \choose 2} a^{n-1}b^2 \ \ + \ ... \ + \ \\[1em] {n \ + \ 1 \choose n-1} a^2b^{n-1} \ \ + \ {n \ + \ 1 \choose n} ab^n \ \ + \ {n \ + \ 1 \choose n \ + \ 1} b^{n\ + \ 1}, \end{gathered} } \end{equation}\]

which in summation form yields our desired result of the binomial theorem for \(n+1\),

\[\begin{equation} (a+b)^{n+1} = \sum^{n+1}_{k=0} {{n+1} \choose k} a^{{n+1}-k}b^k. \end{equation}\]

\(\rule{0.5em}{0.5em}\)

References

AoPS. 2021. “Binomial Theorem.” https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Binomial_Theorem.

Goss, David. 2011. “The Ongoing Binomial Revolution.” https://arxiv.org/abs/1105.3513.
